perturbation.original_text: Owner's Lender" means any Person providing senior or subordinated construction, debt or equity financing or refinancing for or in connection with the development, construction, purchase, or installation of the Facility or any part thereof, including any equity and tax investor providing financing or refinancing in connection therewith, and any trustee or agent acting on their behalf, and any Person providing interest rate protection agreements to hedge any of the foregoing debt obligations.
perturbation.changed_text: "Owner's Funder" means any Person providing debt financing or refinancing for or in connection with the installation of the Facility or any part thereof.
perturbation.explanation: The term 'Owner's Lender' is changed to 'Owner's Funder' and its definition is narrowed, removing references to equity financing, equity and tax investors, and interest rate protection agreements. This could create confusion about the scope of rights and obligations related to different types of financial stakeholders.

perturbation.original_text: During the Warranty Period, Operator shall determine (i) for each full calendar month (the "One- Month Power Performance Warranty Period") within five (5) Business Days after the end of such month and (ii) for the most recent Look Back Period (the "One-Year Power Performance Warranty Period", and, together with the One-Month Power Performance Warranty Period, each a "Power Performance Warranty Period"), whether the Bloom Systems in the Portfolio during such Power Performance Warranty Period have delivered to the Interconnection Point the Minimum kWh during such Power Performance Warranty Period (the "Power Performance Warranty"). If such Power Performance Warranty calculation indicates that the Actual kWh of the Bloom Systems was less than the Minimum kWh during such Power Performance Warranty Period, then Operator shall so notify Owner in writing of the basis of its determination and Owner may make a claim under Section 2.5. An example of a Power Performance Warranty calculation for purposes of a Section 2.5 claim is attached as Appendix D.
perturbation.changed_text: During the Warranty Period, Operator shall determine (i) for each full calendar month (the "Monthly Power Assurance Period") within five (5) Business Days after the end of such month and (ii) for the most recent Look Back Period (the "Annual Power Guarantee Period", and, together with the Monthly Power Assurance Period, each a "Power Performance Period"), whether the Bloom Systems in the Portfolio during such Power Performance Period have delivered to the Interconnection Point the Minimum kWh during such Power Performance Period (the "Power Assurance"). If such Power Assurance calculation indicates that the Actual kWh of the Bloom Systems was less than the Minimum kWh during such Power Performance Period, then Operator shall so notify Owner in writing of the basis of its determination and Owner may make a claim under Section 2.5. An example of a Power Performance calculation for purposes of a Section 2.5 claim is attached as Appendix D.
perturbation.explanation: The phrases "One-Month Power Performance Warranty Period" and "One-Year Power Performance Warranty Period" are changed to "Monthly Power Assurance Period" and "Annual Power Guarantee Period" respectively. The "Power Performance Warranty" is now called "Power Assurance". These changes introduce different terminologies for what is essentially the same calculation and notification process, potentially leading to disputes about whether the obligations under "Power Performance Warranty" still apply or if they are now governed by the terms of "Power Assurance."

perturbation.original_text:
Operator represents and warrants to Owner that, during the Term, the Portfolio shall not fail to receive full payment and service under the Tariffs for any of the following reasons:

(i) Operator shall not remain a Qualified Fuel Cell Provider throughout the original term of the QFCP Tariff.

(ii) Operator shall take any action which causes or is likely to cause: (i) Owner not to qualify (or lose qualification) for service under the QFCP Tariff or (ii) the Portfolio not to qualify (or lose qualification) as a Qualified Fuel Cell Project.

(iii) Operator shall have not complied with any of its obligations under the Letter Agreement (including, if so required by the State of Delaware, posting the security referred to in the Letter Agreement upon or prior to the Commencement of Operation of the first Bloom System).
perturbation.changed_text:
Operator represents and warrants to Owner that, during the Term, the Portfolio shall not fail to receive full payment and service under the Tariffs for any of the following reasons:

(i) Operator shall not remain a Certified Fuel Cell Provider throughout the original term of the QFCP Tariff.

(ii) Operator shall take any action which causes or is likely to cause: (i) Owner not to qualify (or lose qualification) for service under the QFCP Tariff or (ii) the Portfolio not to qualify (or lose qualification) as a Renewable Fuel Cell Project.

(iii) Operator shall have not complied with any of its obligations under the Letter Agreement (including, if so required by the State of Delaware, posting the security referred to in the Letter Agreement upon or prior to the Commencement of Operation of the first Bloom System).
perturbation.explanation: The terms “Qualified Fuel Cell Provider” and “Qualified Fuel Cell Project” were modified to be “Certified Fuel Cell Provider” and “Renewable Fuel Cell Project” respectively. It’s unclear whether these terms are interchangeable, especially since the original terms are explicitly defined in the contract's recitals with specific references to REPS Act Section 352(16) and Section 352(17). Using different terms might imply different standards or requirements, causing confusion about whether the provider and project still meet the necessary qualifications for the Tariffs.
